message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high levels of serum cholesterol and triglycerides suggest that the patient has hyperlipidemia and is at risk of developing xanthomas. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are the most commonly seen physical exam findings in patients with hyperlipidemia. Achilles tendon xanthomas, metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthomas, and xanthelasma can also occur but are less frequent findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The laboratory results show high levels of serum cholesterol and serum triglycerides, which are characteristic of familial hypercholesterolemia. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are commonly seen in familial hypercholesterolemia. Achilles tendon xanthomas and metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthomas are also seen in familial hypercholesterolemia, but palmar xanthomas are the most specific finding associated with this condition. Xanthelasma is not commonly seen in familial hypercholesterolemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s laboratory reports show high cholesterol and triglyceride levels, which suggest hyperlipidemia. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are more commonly associated with hyperlipidemia than other options. Achilles tendon xanthomas are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthomas are rare, and xanthelasma may or may not be present in patients with hyperlipidemia. Physical examination of the patient can confirm the presence of palmar xanthomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high levels of serum cholesterol and triglycerides suggest the patient has familial hypercholesterolemia. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are commonly seen in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia. Achilles tendon xanthomas are seen in patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia, while metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthomas are seen in patients with sitosterolemia. Xanthelasma may also be seen in familial hypercholesterolemia, but palmar xanthomas are more specific.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s laboratory results suggest hyperlipidemia, which can be associated with xanthomas. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are commonly seen in patients with hypercholesterolemia. Achilles tendon xanthoma and metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthoma are less common. Xanthelasma is a specific type of xanthoma that appears on the eyelids and is not associated with hyperlipidemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's laboratory results show high levels of serum cholesterol and triglyceride, which can lead to xanthomas. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are a characteristic finding in patients with hyperlipidemia. Achilles tendon xanthomas are found in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia, while metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthomas are found in patients with primary biliary cholangitis. Xanthelasma is a raised yellow plaque on the eyelid and can also be a feature of hyperlipidemia, but it is not the most likely finding in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high levels of serum cholesterol and triglycerides suggest a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are commonly seen in patients with this condition, while the other options are associated with different conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. With the extremely high levels of cholesterol and triglycerides, and the absence of symptoms, it is likely that the patient has familial hypercholesterolemia. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are the most likely physical finding in this condition, which are yellowish nodules found in the creases of the palms. Achilles tendon xanthomas are more commonly seen in heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia, not homozygous. Metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthomas are seen in another condition called cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis. Xanthelasma is a finding in hyperlipidemia but is not specific to familial hypercholesterolemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s serum triglyceride and cholesterol levels are very high, which suggests a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Among the options provided, palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are the most common physical examination finding associated with familial hypercholesterolemia. Achilles tendon xanthoma and metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthoma are less common and xanthelasma is associated with hyperlipidemia in general, not just familial hypercholesterolemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high triglyceride and cholesterol levels suggest the patient has familial hypercholesterolemia. Palmar xanthomas in flexor creases are commonly seen in this condition. Achilles tendon xanthomas and metacarpophalangeal extensor tendon xanthomas are also seen in familial hypercholesterolemia, but palmar xanthomas are the most likely finding on physical examination. Xanthelasma is typically seen in patients with hyperlipidemia, but is not specific to familial hypercholesterolemia.
